div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE

The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: Suakin Postal Service
div.p: On another page we print a letter from our Correspondent at Suakin in which once more complaint is made in connection with the postal communication with that port. To us it appears that in a place of such importance no effort should have made to improve on the state of things obtained 30 years ago. Astonishing as they appear, it is nevertheless true that Suakin to-day only one post per fortnight, and whilst progress has been the watchwear almost every other Government Department in this particular case things remain as the when the late Ismail Pasha began his every reign. What is the reason for this anon condition of things to which attention ha so often drawn to The Egyptian Dover is keenly alive to the necessity of moving the times, and has shown in other qu that it is ready to anticipate necessities i than lag in the race of progress. The J Department, in particular, is enterprising well organised. We have little doubt by Suakin would long since have had its w mail had it remained, as formerly, a | Egyptian port But we cannot help this the merchants and public of Suakin are ii to blame themselves, as had they moved energetically in the matter it could not failed to receive m ire attention at the i; of the Sudan authorities. We believe time since the Egyptian Government inclined to assist the scheme for a frequent and improved mail service, but iog no response the matter was allowed to Whatever may have been the case i past it is plain that some improvement if necessary, and we think it might be com! with an effort to arrange for a more service than now obtains. We are aware such a service would require State assist but if the Italian Government Ends it i while to pay £13,000 a year for a w connecting service between Aden and shown it ought not to be beyond the sources of the Egyptian Government, surely in the end it would be good. The trade is not sufficient to suable « weekly service to be run without financial but as the Sualriu-Berber Railway will be in about a year, a movement of tourist! travelers may eventually be induced, v would go far to repay the cost of sue assistance, by .the money they would spei the railways and in the country generally, present no one goes down to Suakin u compelled, and the tourist is unknown with good communication there is mu interest to be seen in the neighbourhood, when the railway is finished it will be the route for Khartoum and the Sudan.

div.head:
MONDAY'S BATTLE.
RELATIVE POSITINS UNCHANGED.
RUSSIAN'S RESOLUTE DEFENSE

div.p: . General Kuropatkin telegraphs on the 6tb inst.—"Our troops to the west of Mukden continue to take the offensive. They yesterday repulsed 10 attacks by the Japanese. The assaults on the centre and extreme left were also repulsed. '2,000 dead were counted at Kaotuling, where the enemy has withdrawn to the south." (Reuter.)
General Kuropatkin continues resolutely to defend Pushuu. It is yet uncertain whotker he will retire. He must hold Pushun in order to protect his army on tho Sha-Ho. (Reuter.)
Yesterday's battle did not bring 'about any change in the respective positions of the adversaries. It was begun again this-morning. General Kuropatkin is making a vigorous defense of Fushun. (Havas.)

div.head:
Russian Strikes
Fight Among Men.
Police Chief Shot Dead.

div.p: The men at the Putiloff Works exploded two boilers yesterday. A tight followed amongst the men, twenty-two being killed or wounded.
The men are intensely irritated at the arrest and deportation to4be provinces of a number of the elected delegates. The police hope by this step to deprive the men of their leaders.
The Chief of the Police, M. Bielostock, was shot dead whilst trying to disperse the crowd of strikers. (Reuter.)
The Tsar has ordered the closing of the Labour Commission, mentioned on the 20th ult and 2nd inst., owing to the refusal of the workmen to. elect representatives. (Reuter. ,
A ukase has been issued closing the labours of the Cbildlowsky Commission. {Havas.)
The Tsar yesterday granted the rank of lieutenant to 160 naval cadets six months before the proper time. (Reuter,)

div.head: CARNIVAL AT CAIRO.
GHEZIRAH PALACE "CORSO."
div.p: The Cairo Fetes Committee were again unlucky in their weather yesterday for the "Corso" at Gliezireh Palace. As on the occasion of the Battle of Flowers, it was extremely cold, and not the slightest glimpse of son showed during the day. None the less, a large attendance thronged the seats and tribunes in the Gbezireh Palace Gardens, and though fine weather would have undoubtedly brought even larger numbers, still the receipts were considerable and the garden was crowded. Indeed, many of the French and Italian shops were closed during the afternoon, owing to the departure of the proprietors and assistants to take part in or to watch the procession.

The Committee, as well as the Cairo police, had lung ago recognised the impossibility of & procession through the streets of Cairo, and the carriages, as at the Battle of Flowers, were confined to the circular road round the Ghezireh Casino. At 2.30 p.m. the first decorated carriages began to arrive, and By a quarter to 3 the procession was well under way. Among the carriages that took part in it sl, Swiss chAlet, mounted on a car, was especially beautiful ; and a large car, shaped like a bowl, and drawn by three cart horses, contained a huge champagne bottle, round which a party of masked revellers were grouped. Another carriage i hat took part in the procession was decorated in Japanese style and contained two charming Geishas, while a clown, seated astride on A barrel of beer, under an arbor of boughs and some groups of Pierrots, created much amusement Japanese and medical costume, harlequins and dominoes, all took part in tho procession, and all who were present displayed or simulated a great enthusiasm in the throwing of confetti and serpentines, with which the ground became covered. As each carriage passed the judge's stand, and the tribune, it was heavily bombarded, and once or twice the horses showed a tendency to object to these volleys of missiles, but in spite of the crowding the activity of the mounted police, under Captain Vernon Jarvis, prevented any accident.

The baud of the Royal Inuiskilling Fusiliers played a selection of airs, which were greatly appreciated, during the course of the afternoon, and it was not till near nightfall that the crowd began to make their way home. The Fetes Committee deserve great credit for the care with which they had made all the arrangements, and must be condoled with for unfavorable nature of the climatic conditions.

div.p: The Khedive's reception at Abdeen Palace on the occasion of the Moslem New Yar was largely attended.

div.head: DEATH OF MAITRE ALBRECHT.
div.p: We regret to announce the death ol Maitre Albrecht, which took place at about 7 o'clock last night at Dr. Milton's Nursing Home, Cairo. The deceased succumbed to meningitis, following on the terrible injuries he received by falling out of a train at Samalout He was of Swiss origin and 43.years of age, and had a good practice at the bar of the Cairo Mixed Courts.
His wife and brother were at his bedside when lie died. The body is to be taken to Geneva for burial.
We understand that the Railway authorities are not going to make any official enquiry into tho circumstances of the sad accident.

div.head: MAIL SERVICE TO SUAKIN.
PETITION OF INHABITANTS.
div.p: The inhabitants of Suakin, tho leading merchants and Government officials, are preparing a petition which is to be presented to the Moudir of Suakin, complaining about the undue detention of their correspondence at Suez by the postal authorities there. The mails are aot sent on by the special steamers that constantly arrive here for the Sudan Government railways. The captains of two snob s team ere, which arrived here recently; informed me they would have gladly carried the mails hither had they been brought on board at Suez docks. But the Suez postal authorities detain, them, most likely for the Khedivial Mail steamers, which have the monopoly for the carriage of the mails, and they only run their steamers once a fortnight Last year a similar petition was made to Lord Cromer through the Moudir of Suakin, praying his lordship to use his influence to improve the mail servioe, but no change for the better has taken place since last year.

The Khedivial Mail Company has not sufficient steamers to run a weekly servioe. This time of the year their whole attention is oonoentrated on the pilgrim traffic to Jeddah and back to Suez. Consequently Suakin suffers, and even the regular lortnightly steamers, that have to call at Suakin, have sometimes to undergo quarantine a few days at Jeddah, which delays the mails over the fortnight It is hoped that Lord Cromer, the directors ol the Khedivial Mail Company, and Saba Pasha, the Postmaster General, will do something for Suakin this year, as it has grown to be a very important port, and there are thousands of Egyptians and Europeans now residing here.

We have another route for the mails for Egypt and Europe overland vik Berber, but it takes too long as camels carrying the mails to Berber cannot do the journey in less than 8 days, aud from Berber to Cairo there is about a 5 days' journey, which makes a total of 13 days.

div.head: STRANDING OF THE "CAIRO."
div.p: The enquiry into the stranding of the S.S. "Cairo" continues. Captain de Marchi has handed his report to the Italian Consular Judge, which is substantially the same as the atatement he made at the Consulate, namely that he saw a light in the pass and oondudec that it was the light of the pilot boat.
The Commibsion ot enquiry went to the soene of the disaster yesterday. Jibe general opinion appears to be that the situation of the steamer is well-nigh desperate.

8ignor Novelli does not intend toprooeed with the law suit which he entered at the Italian Consular Court, but to transfer the venue to the Mixed Courts, and will jointly cite both "the Society Artistique d'Egypte and the Florio- Rubattino Steam Navigation Company. If he had brought the oase before the Italian Consular Court, there would have been an appeal to Genoa, but by bringing it before the Mixed Courts there will be no difficulty or delay in changing the venue of the appeal.

The Swedish salvage steamer, "Hermes," which arrived at Port Said last week in connection with the raising of the SB. "Congal," came round to Alexandria yesterday in order to attempt the salvage of tbe "Cairo." This morning, at 6 o'clock the vessel went out to the wreck, but was unable to approach her owing- to -a rather high sea running, and was compelled to return to the inner harbour at 10.20 a.zn.
Salvage operations are oonfined to pioking up articles washed from the vessel by the waves.

Among the passengers was Mr. Lawrence, of Pennsylvania, U. S. A., who was oomiog to Egypt with his wife and mother. They had considerable luggage with them. Mr. Laurence has launched a protest against the Florio-Rubattino Company.

Placards have been posted about the town in Italian inviting subscriptions in aid of the poorer passengers, who have lost all their belongings. There were a number of Italian workmen on board, who of course lost everything

div.head: MARRIAGE AT ALEXANDRIA
div.p: REID -- ANGEL

The marriage took place at St Andrew'* Church, Alexandria, on the 28th alto, of Mr. Alexander M. Reid of the E T. Co. LdL, to Miss Ada Elvira Angel, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Angel, Tantah. Rev. H. P. Reid was the officiating minister. The bride was given away by her father, and wore a die*, of soft white silk, trimmed with lace and mousseline de sole, with an embroidered tulle veil with white heather and orange blossom. The bridesmaids were Miss -Daisy and Urn lil, Angel, sisters of the bride, and Miss Grace Routledge, niece of the bride. They wore white Indian silk dresses made with long fichus of chiffon edged with lace. They carried shower bouquets, which, with pearl and sapphire rings, were the giffc$ of the bridegroom. The bride's train was carried by Master Raymond Misrachi, mho was dressed in navy blue velvet with Brussels lace oollar and cuffs. Mr. Herbert Adams acted as "beet man." The bride's mother wore %a black sequined net robe over black silk with a small toque. After the oeretnony at the oburch, a largely attended reception was held at the Hotel Abbat by Mrs. AngeL The happy couple left the same afternoon by the S.S. "Trojan Prinoe" for England, where the honeymoon will be spent. div.head: CHRONIQUE JUDICIAIRE
div.p: TRIBUNUX MIXTES
LA LOI SUCCESSORALE EN EGYPTE ET LES ETRANGERS

La division do Heritage d'up sujot hell«5ui- que vient de sou lever do van t les tribuunnx mixtes une inttross&bte question de droit oo mature saccessorale. Est-ce 1a loi greoque ou 1a loi ^gyptienne qui doit prdsider à la devolution d« successions en Egypte. La'toi locale rtnroie la solution à la loi Rationale du defuut main la loi grecque à son tour la renvoie à la loi locale. Laqaelle dos deux doit l'emporter !

Le tribunal mixte de premiere instance d'Alexandrie devant qui l'affaire avait ltd portde d'abord a interprets la loi mixte dan* le kens que le renvoi de la devolution succcs- sorale à la loi nation&le du defunt est valable m£me loreque cette loi nationale renvoie It son ^totrr à la loi egyptienne.

M. Vatikiotis a fait appel de ce jugement ct l'affaire a ete plaidec la semaine derntere, Comme 1'arrOt de la Cour promot d'etre intdi rossant, nous extrayons et reunions les prim cipaux passages des conclusions do Me Avlo- nftia, avocat de M. Vatikiotis : —

Aux terrnes de 1'art. 77 du Co<lo Civil Mixte ''les successions sont rdgldes par les lois do la nation ft laquelle appartient le ddfunt. Celui- ci dtant sujet helfene, les iutervenants prdten- dent que sa succession doit 6tre rdglde par la h)i belldnique. Or voici comment Tart. 5 du Code Civil greo promulgud en 1856 tranche la question : "la possession, la propridtd et les droits absplus qui en ddcoulent sur les meubles et les immeubles sis en Grtoe sont rdgis par la loi helfenique. La succession toatamentaire ou ab inte>tat est rdgie par la loi de la nation à laqnello appartient le ddfunt, excepts le cas oil il s'aglt-cfimmeiibles sis en Gr&oe, lesquels eu cola sont rdgis par la loi helfenique."

Co texte fait ddpendre la succession aux immeubles du lieu de leur situation. Aux iui- ineubles situds en Grece on appliquera la loi belldnique et aux immeubles situds à Tdtrangcr on appliquera la loi locale. C'eat ainsi qu'il faut interpreter Tart. 5 si l'ou no veut pas que le fegislateur soit taxe d'iucons<*que»ce.

C'est lit du rente 1'interpretation gdudralo donm'e par les commontateurs à la.loi rom&ine sur laquelle s'est caique le droit civil helfene (voir las auteurs cites par Callogos, les arrOts de l'Ardopage N° 43 en 1875 et N° 1*25 en 1901, 1'arrOt de la Cour d'Appel de Patras N" 415 en 1902 —) Tons oes arrOts ^fcablissent clairement qu'en mature de droits successo- raux sur le3 immeubles situ^s à FEtranger et en pai i'jul er, cu-Egypfco, c'est la loi locale qui doit prevaloir aux terrnes mCxnes de la loi helllnique.'

L'interpr^tation donnve à Part. 5 de la loi helltfnique de 1856 par les pins hautes autorites judieiaires du pays, ast ainsi conforme a la doctrine traditionnelle suivaut laquelle la succession aux immeublas est r^gie par la loi du pays do leur situation. En consequence, les sujets helfencs, lorsqu'ils succfcdent à des im- moubtes ritafo à l'«*tranger sont regis, quant aux dits immeubles, non p&s par 1a loi bell£- nique, main par la loi successorale du pays oil Bont situds can immeubles.

Telle est d'ailleura la doctrine du droit irkmjais * (art 3 du Code Napoldon). D'apr&s crilerdoctrine et une jurisprudence constantes, DkUorRep. Lois Nrt 415 dit que le droit des gelis est impnissant pour rdgler la transmission uksbienspar voie de saccession et quelle est ekcliisivement regie par le droit civil de chaque people'suivant la situation des biens. II en est de mdrne en droit Anglo-Amdricain (Westlake, jonlrnal du droit international privd 1881 p: 318.), en droit autrichien (Revue du droit international J886 p. 465), etc. etc.

ta loi dgyptienne, il est vrai, se rdfere.k la lof'dela nation k laquelle appartient le ddfunt, mais pnisqne la loi de cette nation soumet la succession aux immeubles à la loi du lieu de feuY Situation, on ne saurait, sans violer ouver- femdnt les principes consacrds par lee arrdts de t^t^page; appliquer aux iinmoubles Situds en Bgypte et appartenant à la succession d'nii hell^ne, tk l6l belldiiique qui dtablit la devolution successorale.

' Comme, d'aUtre part, Tart 77 du Code mixto s'efi'rSifere à la loi de la nation du ddfunt, on •e toottVe' en presence d'une loi qui s'en rdfere à UBS autre: la lCi dgyptienne qui renvoie à la loflielldillque et celle-ci à son tonr qui.renvoie à celle-lk.

Deux opinions divisent les jurisconsultes sur la question de savoir quelle loi est applicable au cas prdcitd. La doctrine en Grdoe s'est rkllide à lopinion, quiadinetrapplicabilitddela lof dtrangdre (VoirTarticlepublid par M.Streit, le savant ptofesseur do droit international à rUniverBitd d'Atbdnes dont lopinion faitauto- ritd eu dfdce).' Cette dpinion est d'autant plus logique qu'en appliquah^ la lo( dtrangdre on applique en rda- litd la tef beUdnique qui impose le recours à la loi dtrangdre. Par consdquent le juge se con forme à lk lpi belldnique en appliqiiant la loi etrftng&re dgyptienne musulmane. div.head: THE NILE FENS.
By D. G. HOGARTH
div.p: A LOST PROVINCE

This description, however, refers only to • the extreme north of the present marsh land, where still exist great lagoons and a large amphibious population offish-eaters ; where, too, are the sites of several settlements of J'toleiûaic and Homan times, half buried in :hc shiftiug dunes of the seaboard. It is the inland or southern half of the region that, in its present state, looks so little lit ever to have b»'en inhabited by man. Never theWs you may nowhere travel far there without happening on his handiwork. His ancient ports, his half silted canal*, with broken dykes, lurk in all quarters, making au evil harbourage for iusects and traps for the sauguine explorer who thinks to take a bee-line from point to poiut ; but not infrequently they will lead you, if your purpose be to see ancient sites, straight to the mounds, to which theyouce carried traffic s and sweet water- Arrived, you will find the profile of the dusty tell broken by no imposing ruiu, for in this region the Homan builders used but little brick, and the most of that unbaked. But the surface will be strewn with vitreous slags, left by the Arabs, who have burnt what» stone there was lor lime ; with fragments of decaying glass, whose iridescence vies with the brilliant oxides on scraps of oop- per pans or tools or almost illegible coins, which range from the later Ptolemies to the Byzantine and even early Arab times ; with sherds of rotten blue faience and earthenware, paiuted or plain, but all of the commoner kinds.
POOR RESULTS.

In short, it oilers but poor loot in return for all your labour through bog and soapy sand. Nor will you get much more by digging ut a venture, lor these mounds are made mostly of little adobe houses, piled one on nuother, their contents long ago rotted with salt ; and below them you must back through some feet of empty sand, compounded by rain and pressure to the consistency of asphalt, which has been piled upon the lowest ruius to make a dry bed for later habitations, to find at the bottom nothing better than a heap of black Nile mud, brought together by the first builders to raise the town at its foundation above the damp level of the surrounding flats. Now and again the newly come natives, who dig in these mounds, on their own behalf or that of the Behera Society, for the virgin earth, containing a suspicion of nitre, which exists on all ancieut sites in Egypt, or for ready-made kiln-dried bricks of Homan times, turn up drums or capitals of small columns, an inscription or two, or even such a sculptured Homan head as is now kept by the Society at Kum Wahal. But those are rare rewards, and you will more probably have to be oontent with the stirring of your imagination. These desolate trophies of a dominance over Nature, carried to a poiut to which our own age is now painfully trying to attain, are the trophies of Imperial Rome. I have done what I can to identify those little lost towns, and I find among them two capitals of provinces in the time of Hadrian, three Byzantine bishoprics, and as many towns that were not episcopal sees, but have left a name in the early Arab history of Egypt. But all were most obscure places. The wonder is, not that great towns stood here, but any towns at ail.
THE DELTA NILES.

These mounds of the North Delta are disposed iu three chains, running from south to north, which seem to align the courses of two of the lost ancient Niles, the Tkermutiac (or Pharmuthiac) and the A thribitic, and that of a central u.ain canal, Uow known as the Bulir Hashed. There have been considerable changes in the courses of the Delta Niles. For instance the westernmost, the Great Nile, or Agatha- daemon, which used to flow out near Canopus (Aboukir), now flows only down the bed of what was a secondary stream, the Toly, aDd issues at the old Bolbitinic estuary, the modern Rosetta mouth. It is curious to uote how utterly the traces of its ancient channel have been effaced in about a thousand years. It used to pass by the Greek city of Naukratis, and therfc perhaps its course can still be traced in the hollow between the site and a small iuound, which is evidently the remains of a Leaped-up bank such as would have aligned the river. The Thermuthiac and AthrilAtic Niles are now represented respectively by the canalised B&hr Nashart and the Bahr Tirah, but the modern streams do not run continuously in the old beds. The aetual Athribiric channel I discovered in midmarsh, sweeping jmst a chain of mounds ; it bas long been dry, but its dykes still remain, defiuiug a bed about 350 feet wide.
A PRIMITIVE REGION.

So much for the true marsh land. North of it lies the lagoon district, fenced from the sea by a broad belt of dunes. It shows in most respects a sharp contrast to the fens, being a region comparatively rich and populous, and of very old settlement; but it is neither less remote, nor better known to the casual tourist in Egypt Nor is it one whit less interesting, for nowhore in the Nile land is to be seen a region more primitive, or a more rfccent oontact of aboriginal Eastern folk and Western in-com ere. Here the tjo elements still meet almost as strangers, each unalloyed by the other. Indeed, with the seaward part of the district it may still be said that the European has nothing to do. If one* in many moons a British inspector of coast* guard or canal outfalls pay a flying visit, he will be stared at a moment and forgotten, like some strange bird tbat has lighted suddenly on the lagoons.
EGYPT'S COASTLINE.
To reach the lakes you must descend one of greater canals of the Central Delta before

the summer dryness in a boat of the lightest dr.-* light, and, leaving the last of the locks far behind, pass beyond all habitations of Nile busUEhdmen into an amphibious Limbo, in d^itSt between land and water where no life of ui !. abides continually. Soon the canal dykes cesse on cither hand, and the banks fall to a few inches in height. Let your boat slip* on a m'.'.Q or two more. The flood brims bank hirf\ its wavelets slop on to the land, and, lo ! you find there is uo longer land either to right or left, behind or before. Undefined by any line of coast, Egypt has slid at the last under her own waters and become invisible at less than a mile away, and the voyager finds himself adrift ou a sea, seeming limitless, so low aie its shores, and bottomless, so turbid are its harassed waves. Yet, in fact, if a tall man let himself down into any part of the great area of this lakethe surface will scarcely rise to his armpit.

Holding on its* course, the boat passes at once out of that dead world of the fen into one of singular life, a life notof land any longer, but water, whereof forewarning was given some miles up thecanalatthelastsettlemeutofman. There fi-hing nets hang to wind and sun, and a little fleet of keelless craft collects any afternoon while a Copt sells its draught of fish at auction. The catch of each crew is offered as a whole. A salesman squatting over the mat stirs the palpitating heap to wurk the larger fish to the top ; a fat oue he picks out aud puts by in a palm-leaf pannier for the auctioneer, a second for the writer, a third for himself. The rest is bid for at prioes ranging from lento forty piastres, sold, packed on asses, and despatched to feed the marshmen for many miles around. You will not sail a mile on the lake unamazed at its scaly wealth. Silvery bodies leap by tens and twenties from the ochrous surface, and the water boils with the passing of shoals. Boats at anchor, boats adrift with trailing nets, boats under full sail, multiply as one goes north and east, till all the loneliness of the L.mto is torgotten. All round the horizon spriug groves of perpendicular poles crossed by poles oblique, the masts and lateen yards of invisible hulls, moored by invisible islets whose sandy levels are all but awash, i know not how many craft ply on.
LAKE BURULLOS

but the tale must run into hundreds and that of the fisher folk to thousands—the latter of a bloud type dignified with some of that energy and -reserve which are seldom altogether wauting to men whose nusiuess is on great waters. 1 had neither opportunity nor occasion to study them closely, but received a clear impression of their racial antiquity. The general typo of features seems to be that sharply marked and over refined sort which one associates with an old inbred race, and the women often reminded me strongly of tho characteristic type on the Egyptian monuments. An an thro pome tris t might find not a little to interest him in this remote and secluded corner of the Nile Valley.

The new land does not begin to rise on the north-eastern horizon till a dozen barren islets have slipped astern. First emerge the higher dunes, uplifted in & shimmering mirage, rose { and yellow like low cumdus clouds touched by suuset These run one into another till they become a continuous range, spotted with black tufts, which are the plumes of half- buried palms. A cluster of huts to left with upstanding blocks is the village of Borg, with its dismantled fort and coastguard station, situated on all that remains oi the Be benny tic estuary of the Nile. A rank odour ot curing comes down the wind, lor there are dried the putrescent fish on which half the poor of Lower Egypt. live. To right and ahead, as you wear round the last island and set a course due east, a large dark stain resolves listel into a little town with a minaret or two set on a hillock and backed by the golden dunes and the palms. A forest of naked masts and yards lies out on the lake; it is the fleet of Baltim, and the chief settlement of the Burullos fisher-folk and old episcopal see of Parallos, whose sound, corrupted on Arab lips, makes the modern name.
THE ICTHOPHAGI FELLAHEEN.

So flat is the lake floor that a great way from the margin the water is still but inches deep, and the grounded feluccas discharge their freight on to the backs to camels, which are trained against Nature both to receive their loads standing and to plash unconcerned a mile out in the inland sea. So far out also as to be dimly seen, naked children roam all day and every day, plying in either hand tiny javelins or little caatmg-ueU, fishing as their first forefathers fished ; and I have seen no healthier or happier babies than this amphibious brood, whose playground is the lagoon. The fathers and mothers also seem to pass their days al Jretco on the great expanse ot sandy beach, coopering boats, buying and selling fish, chattering, sleeping in the sun. It is astonishing in Egypt to see any life so clean. Here is no longer the Nile mud, a viscous ink when wet and a fouling dust if dry, but the purest ruin of calcareous rooks. Even the huts are not clay-built, but of ancient Roman bricks dug out of the mounds that lie to south of the lagoon, and long ago mellowed to a dusky red which harmonizes to admiration with the yellow dunes and the palms. Less solid beehive shelters, byres, and fences are plaited of dry palm-fronds. It is
A MOST SINGULAR BIT IN EGYPT

this long sand-belt, which fences the northern sea-made, for the most part, one must suppose, of the detrites of a barrier range of prehistoric islands, themselves compact of scuh a soft lime ton eas that on which Alexandria is built. Coming into it out o the great Nile-flats, one thinks it is a veritable highland, and climbing painfullt over the sliding dunes hardly notes that every deeper hollow falls again to the Nile Level. Yet so it is and therefore palms may be planted deep, and they will bear abundantly, though the dunes, in the constant eastward progression, bury them to the

spring of their plumes. In the troughs of the sand wave* potatoes and tomatoes are grown behind long alignments of sheltering wattles ; nor is a wild waxy pasture wauting, whose roots trail to incredible length,'even to fifty or sixty feet, through the sand to seek the ground moisture which somewhere will not fail them. You may find a similar tract by taking train from Alexandria towards Rosetta, and see a village like Baltim in Edku by its lake ; but there is no view west of the Nile to rival tbat from the higher dunes of Burullos ; nothing like that great forest of sand-choked palms in the hollow that lies between the lake dunes and the higher golden range by the open sea ; nothing like the ample prospect of the Lake Burullos itself, with its northern fringe of fLher-settlements, its beach alive with fishing- folk, and its wafers dotted with their hulls and sails. It i* no longer familiar k^ypt, as one knows it, but a laud of even more primæval life sjpd even less change.
THE FUTURE.

Idle agents of change, however, are abroad, and the time is not far off when the limits of cultivation wül be pushed northward as far as the southern shores of the lake. That is as far as they wore pushed eighteen hundred years ago by Imperial Rome. Aud perhaps the time is not so much farther off when the lake itself will be cut off from the sea aud its bed drained and parcelled out into arable plots, suffering the . ame change tbat in the past ten years has c >iuc over the lagoon of Aboukir and now thiealeus that ol Edku. The severest critics of British rule iu Egypt admit that at least it bus resulted in certain ameliorations of the lot of the agricultural Egyptian—in his having better security of tenure and a larger enjoyment of the fruits of his labour. Nor, again, is it denied that we are improving his food and the sanitary conditions under which he has to live. We may fairly take credit (if credit there be) for two consequences of these ameliorations — for the steady inorease in population and the obvious growth of a land- hunger among the people. The one is pushing a growii g proportion of the fellaheen out ot their native vidage**, the other inducing the surplus to make, not for the towns, but for the unappropriated arable lands. The vacuum which sucks that surplus nowadays is the Northern Delta. There alone, in the strait and teeming valley of the Nile, is yet room aud to spare ; * and there will be seeu in the near future the greatest expansion and modification of Nature by man.
THE CAPE TO CAIRO RAILWAY.

A cahlo has been thrown across the Zambesi River at the site of the Victoria Palls Bridge. It consists of u meel rope about 870ft. long and eight aud a half inches in circumference, aud has a breaking strain of 275 tons. Owing to the j geological formation below the Victoria Falls no scaffolding could be erected for building the bridge, and it was decided to erect an aerial cableway, by which the material could be transported across the Zambesi, so that tho bridge could be constructed from each hank at the same time. Simultaneously with the construction of the bridge, the railway extension to Kalomo, one hundred miles north of the

Zambesi, the capital of North-Western Rhodesia, is being proceeded with and when this is completed, the line will be extended from the Kalmo to the Broken Hill Mine. AIn addition to the bridgework all the permanent way material, rolling stock, and stores necessary for three extentensions are being conveyed across the river by the cabe-way. Eight hundred tons can be taken across the Zambesi in a day.

div.head: CHASE FOR A BRIDE
div.p: A REPORTER'S SUCCESS.

Not often (says a Manchester evening paper) has a reporter to interview a Bride on hei Wedding morning, but a Manchester pressman recently attempted this delicate task. He reached his destination only in time fr examine the oonfetti which bad greeted the departing oouple. But a week later the per sistent re{K»rter found the newly-wedded pair; Mr. and Mrs. Ridgard, at their home, 29, Walton street, Miles Flatting.

His errand was to obtain from the Bride some particulars of a matter which had reached the Editor's ears. In reply to questions Mrs. Ridgard said : "I shall be twenty ,years of age next week. Three or four yean ago I suffered terribly from a weak heart and anaemia. Various remedies were prescribed for me, but I only grew weaker and weaker. I had no appetite. Life was a burden. 1 was so weak and ill that if 1 only walked across the garden I was ex hausted. I was little more than skin and bone."
'There has evidently been a great change !"

The blushing bride rejoined : "Aboçt six months ago 1 was induoed by friends to try Dr. Williams' pink pills for paie people. I had often beard of their cures, and have a friend who suffered, like me, from / amend a, and was cured alter two boxes of these pills.

"After the second box, I, too, began to feel an improvement, aud this increased with each suooeediug box. My appetite became stronger I could sleep better ; I lelt fresher in the morning. In short, new life and new strength had been given me. My recovery was steady and gradual. I have takeu nine boxes altogether, and now I am quite well and strong again.

This bride of a week looked as happy as she is healthy; and Mrs. Wiilans, her mother, gladly added her own testimony to the value of Dr. Williams' pink pills, which had cured her, she said, of bronchitis and biliousness.

Mrs. Wiilans, a healthy and bnxom widow, was, like her daughter, full of praise for the cures which had been effected in her own household by this medioina It is by making new blood that these pills are able to core so many different ailments—anosmia in the case of Mrs. Ridgard and her friend, bronchitis as well as bile in the case ot Mra Wiilans. Dr. Williams' medicine oo., Holbom-vioduct, London, send a box of the genuine pills post free lor two and ninepenoe ; but they can be had of all medicine dealers, provided care is taken to see that the package bears the toll name, Dr. Williams' pink pills for pale people—seven words. It is well known that substitutes never cure, and they should be firmly refused. Consumption, decline, eczema, fits, gout, heart disease, rheumatism, paralysis, looomotor ataxy, Su Vitus' dance, are among the other ailments the geuuine pills have cured. Ladies who know why they need new blood oftener than their brothers and husbands, will find the medicine a revelation.
Sold in Egypt by all chemists at P.T. 13 per box or P.T. 70 per 6 boxes. Can be bought at th«Tgeneral dépôt : Max Fischer, Cairo, Hotel du Nil St. (1st floor), and Alexandria, Rue Stamboul, No. 8.

div.head: KIDNEY DISEASE IS FATAL IF NEGLECTED
HAVE YOU SUSPECTED YOUR KIDNEYS?
div.p: When the kidneys get ill the back gives out
But the back is not to blame.
The ache comes from the kidnoya, which, lie under the small of the back.
Therefore dull pain in the beck, or sharp, quick twinges, are warnings of sick kidneys— warnings of kidney trouble.
Plasters and liniments will not cure a bad back, for they cannot reach the kidneys tiiat cause it

Doan's backache kidney pills reach the kidneys themselves; this is a special kidney and bladder medicine, and it drives ont of the body all the liquid poisons, and crystallis­ed impurities that cause disease. Doan's backache kidney pills heal the diseased sur face of the kidneys and bladder.

Kidney trouble affects different peoole differently bat the common signs are back­ache, irregular kidney action, rheumatism, nervousness, languor, dizziness, irregular heart, book quickly affected by oold, sleeplessness, irritability, puffiness beneath the eyes, swollen ankles and limbs, headaohes, despondency, too much or too little urine, sediment from the urine, gravel, and bladder troubles.

Doan's backache kidney pills are for sale by all chemists and druggists for P.T. 13 per box, or P.T. 71 for 6 boxes ; or they may be had by post from the general agent for Egypt, Mr. Max Fischer, Hotel du Nil N3t, Mousky St, Cairo.

div.head: THE DEADLY MOSQUITO.
div.p: "It is sufficent to say Protection from the mosquit bites affords complete immunity in ages in all its forms. . . Yellow fever , likes ages, has been shwn to be early by a Misquito."- Times 28th September 1904
ANTIKITO CREAM (Regd.)

This wonderful preparation- which is most delightfukky refreshing to use- is the outcome of long laboratory research, During the last five years it has been thoroughly tested in all parts of the world. By its use the fatal mosqiro as well as FLIES, gnats and all flying insects, are set at definance. It is abolsutely infallible as a preventitve, and is guarunteed to be free from carbolic and other deleterious ingredients. It is neither sticky nor greasy and one application to the exposed parts affords protection for house, Invaluable for hospital use and should be in the kit of all expeditions, It is better than Quinine. Protects you from flies.
ANTIKITO CREAM is manufactured under export supervision in the Syndicates's own laboratory and is put up in two sizes Proprietros: ANITKITO SYNDICATE, LTD., 6 Great Portland Street, LONDON
